{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} [[File:40 Window world map.PNG|thumb|upright=1.5|The nations in the 10/40 Window]] The '''10/40 Window''' is a term coined by [[mission (Christian)|Christian missionary]] strategist and Partners International CEO [[Luis Bush]] in 1990<ref name=time>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/1101030630/map/ |title=The 10/40 Window |work=Time |date=June 30, 2003| accessdate= March 1, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070428234833/http://www.time.com/time/covers/1101030630/map/| archivedate= April 28, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->}}. The link is to the map, which is part of an extensive cover story.</ref> to refer to those regions of the eastern hemisphere, plus the European and African part of the western hemisphere, located between [[10th parallel north|10]] and [[40th parallel north|40 degrees north]] of the [[equator]], a general area that was purported to have the highest level of socioeconomic challenges<ref name=wfb>{{cite book |title=World FactBook}}, edition available in 1990. At the time, the authoritative source for socioeconomic and political metrics for every nation. Extreme poverty was denoted as under US$500 per capita GNP (in 1990 dollars). Human suffering was measured by the Quality of Life index, precursor to today's [[Human Development Index]]</ref><ref>See the ''Analysis'' section of this article for research-based details and cited references.</ref> and least access to the Christian message and Christian resources<ref>"Access" is generally defined using a variety of metrics. What is least controversial is those areas with least access throughout history, as all metrics for such areas are zero or close to zero. Examples of metrics used include the presence of (Christian) work and workers (of any kind, whether community development, health, business, child care, house servants, etc), media in an appropriate language (print, TV, radio, web, etc.),</ref><ref name=ow>[[Operation World]] provides a concise well-researched/cited data summary for each nation</ref><ref name=wce>{{cite book|last=Barrett|first=David B.|author2=Kurian, George T.|author3=Johnson, Todd M. (eds.)|title=World Christian Encyclopedia|edition=2nd|url=http://www.oup-usa.org/isbn/0195079639.html|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-507963-9|pages=1739pp|year=2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030206213312/http://www.oup-usa.org/isbn/0195079639.html|archivedate=February 6, 2003}} Much of its data is available online at the ({{cite web |url=http://worldchristiandatabase.org/wcd/ |title=World Christian Database |publisher=Brill |accessdate=March 1, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070304152957/http://worldchristiandatabase.org/wcd/# |archivedate=March 4, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}) Mind-numbing in its details (with some areas of unique value), but the introduction and definitions in the paper edition are quite helpful to understanding.</ref> on the planet.
The concept behind the ''10/40 Window'' highlights these three elements (as of data available in 1990): an area of the world with great poverty and low quality of life, combined with lack of access to Christian resources. The Window forms a band encompassing [[Sahara]]n and Northern Africa, as well as almost all of Asia (West Asia, Central Asia, South Asia, East Asia and much of Southeast Asia). Roughly two-thirds of the world population lived in the 10/40 Window, and it is predominantly [[Muslim]], [[Hindu]], [[Buddhist]], [[animist]], [[Jewish]], or [[atheist]]. Many governments in the 10/40 Window are officially or unofficially opposed to Christian work of any kind within their borders.<ref name=wfb/><ref name=ow/><ref name=wce/>
==Origin== This region of the world was previously known to Christians as the "resistant belt", as noted by [[Luis Bush]] at the 1989 [[Second International Congress on World Evangelization|Lausanne II Conference in Manila]]. In 1990, Bush's research led to a meeting with Pete Holzmann, a leader of the team developing the first PC-based [[GIS]] software.<ref>Atlas GIS, produced by Strategic Mapping Inc., was the first PC Geographic Information System.{{cite news|url=http://www.gismonitor.com/news/newsletter/archive/040501.php |title=ESRI Retires ArcCAD and Atlas GIS| accessdate= September 21, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070925180632/http://www.gismonitor.com/news/newsletter/archive/040501.php| archivedate= September 25, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->}}</ref> They analyzed the region using a box between 10 and 40 degrees north latitude and called it the ''10/40 box''. A few weeks later, Bush and his wife Doris were inspired to rename it the ''10/40 Window'', stating that this region ought to be seen as a "window of opportunity".{{citation needed |date= September 2007}} The analysis and concept was a generalization that focuses on a region, not a sharp boundary defining what is a priority, and what is not. For this reason, many missiologists prefer to use the phrase ''10/40 Window region''.
Before being called the "resistant belt", the Islamic portions of this region, as well as selected unreached Buddhist and Hindu areas, were referred to as the "unoccupied fields" by [[Samuel Marinus Zwemer|Samuel Zwemer]], in his book by that same title, published in 1911.<ref>{{cite book |last=Zwemer|first=Samuel M. |title=The Unoccupied Mission Fields of Africa and Asia|location=New York|publisher=Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign Missions|page=260|year=1911}}</ref>
==Controversy== Some<ref>Verbal and online discussions, no documentation available outside of Wikipedia itself.</ref> have objected to such a broad-brush term which seems to imply a unifying characteristic of the 10/40 Window when in fact no large area of the planet is completely homogenous in cultural attributes.
The 1990 research data states: * this part of the world was home to the largest populations living in deep poverty and lowest [[quality of life]];<ref name=wfb/><ref name=mappoor/><ref name=mapqual/> * this part of the world did have least access to Christian resources. Note the emphasis on ''access'' not ''percent Christian''. The West has ubiquitous access to such resources; this area of the world did and does not.<ref name=ow/><ref name=wce/>
This research deals in overall population characteristics. The ''10/40 Window'' is a term that helps people visualize the general area of the analysis, where the above characteristics are generally true, but with exceptions proving it is only a generalization. Some examples of the exceptions: * The 10/40 Window article refers to the "poorest of the poor" living in that region (based on late-1980s per-capita [[GNP]] under US$500).<ref name=wfb/><ref name=ow/> Of the three billion people living in such poverty-stricken nations, 82% lived in the 10/40 Window. Yet the 10/40 Window also includes nations such as [[South Korea]] and Japan. In the late 20th century, Japan boasted the world's third largest economy, and South Korea the eleventh. Such nations were strong throughout the late 20th century. * Geographically, the 10/40 Window includes the [[Philippines]] and [[Portugal]], which both have a Roman Catholic Christian majority; [[Greece]], where almost 98% of the population belonged to the [[Greek Orthodox Church]]; and South Korea, which is home to the largest single congregation church in the world<ref>The largest congregation is in Seoul ([[Yoido Full Gospel Church]]) {{cite news |url=http://mondaymorninginsight.typepad.com/monday_morning_insight_we/2005/05/the_top_10_chur.html |title=The Top 10 Churches in the World (by size)| accessdate= August 20, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070927162953/http://mondaymorninginsight.typepad.com/monday_morning_insight_we/2005/05/the_top_10_chur.html| archivedate= September 27, 2007 <!--Added by DASHBot-->}}</ref> and is also the second largest missionary-sending nation in the world.<ref name=misinc>{{cite news |url=http://www.ctlibrary.com/ct/2006/march/16.28.html |title=Missions Incredible|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061107083606/http://www.ctlibrary.com/ct/2006/march/16.28.html|archivedate=November 7, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The 10/40 Window does not encompass [[Indonesia]] or Sri Lanka, nations that had very little access to Christian resources.<ref name=ow/>
==Gaining widespread use== Over the years, the 10/40 Window has evolved from a specialist term used by Christian [[Missiology|missiologists]] to assumed vocabulary for Christians in the West.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charismamag.com/display.php?id=792 |title=Becoming Global Christians in the 21st Century By Justin Long – Charisma Magazine, (2001) |publisher=Charismamag.com |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charismamag.com/display.php?id=1575 |title=Islam and China's Christmas By David Aikman – Charisma Magazine, (2002) |publisher=Charismamag.com |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/tcw/2003/001/11.12.html |title=Marli Spieker | Today's Christian Woman | Your Life. Your Faith. Your World, (2003) |publisher=Christianitytoday.com |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/workplace/articles/issue9-faithatwork.html |title=The Faith at Work Movement: Opening "The 9 to 5 Window" – FaithInTheWorkplace.com, (2004) |publisher=Christianitytoday.com |date=October 30, 2011 |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncrcafe.org/node/438 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927213817/http://ncrcafe.org/node/438 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |title=Evangelicals look to '10/40 Window' | National Catholic Reporter Conversation Cafe, (2006) |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref> It is an emerging term in the secular press<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/covers/1101030630/map/ TIME: The 10/40 Window]</ref> and can be found in press style glossaries.<ref>{{cite web|author=ANN Glossary |url=http://news.adventist.org/styleguide/glossary.html?&template=printer.html |title=ANN Glossary |publisher=News.adventist.org |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref> Non-western writers and organizations also refer to the 10/40 Window.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macsa.co.za/faq.html |title=FAQ |publisher=Macsa.co.za |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.opendoors.org.za/content/view/239/21/ |title=Welcome to Open Doors South Africa |access-date=March 1, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213040807/http://www.opendoors.org.za/content/view/239/21/ |archive-date=February 13, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{ko icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20010702020031/http://mission.swim.org/srilanka/leesh/ Society for world mission/mission network/Srilanka-ŔĚ˝ÂČŻźąąłťç]</ref> In addition, those opposed to the idea of evangelism make use of the term.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://csindy.com/csindy/2003-04-03/cover.html|title=Guerrillas for God : Inside Colorado Springs' modern day missionary boot camp|publisher=Colorado Springs Independent|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040117125117/http://csindy.com/csindy/2003-04-03/cover.html|archivedate=2004-01-17|accessdate=May 21, 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=Lightman |first=Alan |url=http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/04/15/in_touch/index_np.html?pn=2|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210204511/http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/04/15/in_touch/index_np.html?pn=2|archivedate=2006-12-10 |title=Onward Christian soldiers |publisher=Dir.salon.com |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otherwise.net/?page_id=296 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215220934/http://www.otherwise.net/?page_id=296 |archivedate=2008-02-15 |title=otherwise |accessdate=November 20, 2011}}</ref>
==Analysis== The original 1990 GIS 10/40 Window analysis produced several insights, among them showing that the nations of the 10/40 Window represented (as of the research date): *82% of the poorest of the world's poor (per capita GNP less than US$500 per year),<ref name=mappoor>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=The Poorest Countries & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref> *84% of those with lowest quality of life (life expectancy, infant mortality, and literacy),<ref name=mapqual>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=Quality of Life & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref> *the hub of the world's major non-Christian religions (Islam, Buddhism, Hinduism, etc.,)<ref name=maprel>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=Three Religious Blocks & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref><ref name=mapislam>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=Islam & & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref> *close to 100% of those who were both most-poor ''and'' had least-access to Christian resources (two-dimensional analysis)<ref name=mapprun>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=The Poor, The Unevangelized, & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref> *The least Christian resource investment<ref>Well below 10 percent in any of the study populations. Each of the cited maps provides side data on population, Christian involvement, etc in the various study populations (poor, low quality of life, non-Christian, etc)</ref> and least sharing of the Christian message<ref name=mapleast>{{cite map|publisher=AD2000|title=The 55 Least Evangelized Countries & The 10/40 Window|edition=August 1, 1990|cartography=GMI/GRDB}}</ref>
The GIS analysis utilized country-level data from the Operation World<ref name=ow/> almanac, the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]],<ref name=wce/> and the [[World Factbook]].<ref name=wfb/>
===Non-Christians in the 10/40 Window by religion=== The first edition GIS analysis maps highlighted the three major religious blocks in the 10/40 Window, specifically the majority Muslim, Hindu and Buddhist nations. Population estimates at the time for the year 2000 (from Operation World) were given as: * 28 Muslim countries, 1.1 billion population est. (2000) * 2 Hindu countries, 1.1 billion population est. (2000) * 8 Buddhist countries, 237 million population est. (2000)
[http://home.snu.edu/~hculbert/1040.htm Later updates] have been based more on census data and other estimates rather than forward-looking population estimates. The cited reference provides the following estimate of "[[unreached]]" non-Christian populations in the 10/40 Window: *865 million Muslims *550 million Hindus *275 million Buddhists *140 million in 2550 tribal groups (mainly animist) *17 million Jews<ref>Note that this number is higher than the census-based world total of 14 million. However, even authoritative [http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Judaism/jewpop.html Jewish sources] state that many Jews do not identify themselves in population censuses.</ref>
===Nations in the 10/40 Window=== The 10/40 Window originally encompassed the following 57 countries. An expanded list including some important nearby nations is offered by the [[Joshua Project]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://joshuaproject.net/resources/articles/10_40_window |title=What is the 10/40 Window? |publisher=joshuaproject.net |accessdate=May 21, 2018}}</ref>
{{div col|colwidth=20em}} # [[Afghanistan]] # [[Algeria]] # [[Bahrain]] # [[Bangladesh]] # [[Benin]] # [[Bhutan]] # [[Burkina Faso]] # [[Cambodia]] # [[Chad]] # [[China]] # [[Cyprus]] # [[Djibouti]] # [[Egypt]] # [[Eritrea]] # [[Ethiopia]] # [[The Gambia|Gambia]] # [[Guinea]] # [[Guinea-Bissau]] # [[India]] # [[Iran]] # [[Iraq]] # [[Israel]] (including [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]) # [[Japan]] # [[Jordan]] # [[North Korea|Korea (North)]] # [[South Korea|Korea (South)]] # [[Kuwait]] # [[Laos]] # [[Lebanon]] # [[Libya]] # [[Mali]] # [[Malta]] # [[Mauritania]] # [[Morocco]] # [[Myanmar]] # [[Nepal]] # [[Niger]] # [[Oman]] # [[Pakistan]] # [[Qatar]] # [[Saudi Arabia]] # [[Senegal]] # [[Sudan]] ([[South Sudan#Independence (2011)|at the time]] including [[South Sudan]]) # [[Syria]] # [[Taiwan]] # [[Tajikistan]] # [[Thailand]] # [[Tunisia]] # [[Turkey]] # [[Turkmenistan]] # [[United Arab Emirates]] # [[Vietnam]] # [[Western Sahara]] # [[Yemen]] {{div col end}}
These were all [[Old World]] nations (mostly in the [[eastern hemisphere]]) with at least 50 percent of their land area falling within 10 to 40 degrees latitude as of 1990. (The list also included [[Gibraltar]] and [[Macau]], which are not independent nations.) See the [http://www.ad2000.org/1040coun.htm list of nations] in the original study.

The '''1888–1893 Uprisings of Hazaras''' occurred when the [[Treaty of Gandomak]] was signed and the [[Second Anglo-Afghan War]] ended in 1880, causing [[Abdur Rahman Khan]] to set out on a goal to bring Hazarajat and [[Kafiristan]] under his control. He launched several campaigns in Hazarajat due to resistance from the Hazaras in which his forces committed atrocities. The southern part of Hazarajat was spared as they accepted his rule, while the other parts of Hazarajat rejected Abdur Rahman and instead supported his uncle, [[Sher Ali Khan]]. In response to this Abdur Rahman waged a war against tribal leaders who rejected his policies and rule."HAZĀRA: ii. HISTORY". Alessandro Monsutti (Online ed.). United States: [[Encyclopædia Iranica]]. December 15, 2003. Retrieved 2012-08-09. http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/hazara-2 Abdur Rahman arrested Syed Jafar, chief of the [[Sheikh Ali (Hazara tribe)|Sheikh Ali]] Hazara tribe, and jailed him in [[Mazar-e-Sharif]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} ==First uprising== The first Hazara uprising against Abdur Rahman Khan took place between 1888 and 1890. When Emir Abdur Rahman's cousin, Mohammad Eshaq, revolted against him, tribal leaders of the Sheikh Ali Hazaras joined the revolt. The revolt was short lived as the Emir extended his control over large parts of Hazarajat. After all of Sheikh Ali Hazaras' chiefs were sent to [[Kabul]], opposition within the leadership of Sawar Khan and Syed Jafar Khan continued against the government troops, but at last were defeated. Taxes were imposed and Afghan administrators were sent to occupied places, where they subjugated the people with abuses. People were disarmed, villages were looted, local tribal chiefs were imprisoned or executed, and the better lands were confiscated and given to Afghan [[nomad]]s ([[Kuchis]]). ==Second uprising== The second uprising occurred in the Spring of 1892. According to [[Syed Askar Mousavi]], the cause of the uprising was an assault on the wife of a Hazara Chieftain by Afghan soldiers. The families of both the man and his wife, deciding that death was one hundred times better than such humiliation, killed the soldiers involved and attacked the local garrison, from whence they recovered their confiscated arms". Several other tribal chiefs who supported Abdur Rahman now turned against him and joined the rebellion which rapidly spread through the entire Hazarajat. In response to the rebellion, the Emir declared a "[[jihad]]" against the Shias{{Cite web|title = Refworld {{!}} World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples – Afghanistan : Hazaras|url = http://www.refworld.org/docid/49749d693d.html|website = Refworld|access-date = 2016-01-16}} and raised an army of up to 40, 000 soldiers, 10, 000 mounted troops, and 100,000 armed civilians (most of which were Pashtun nomads). He also brought in [[British Raj|British]] military advisers to assist his army.{{cite book |last= Mousavi|first= Sayed Askar|title= The Hazaras of Afghanistan: An Historical, Cultural, Economic and Political Study|origyear= 1997|year= 1998 |publisher= St. Martin's Press|location = Richmond, NY|isbn= 0-312-17386-5}} ==Third uprising== {{Infobox civilian attack |title=Crackdown on
Third Hazara Uprising |image= Abdur rahman.jpg |image_size = 125px |caption= [[Abdur Rahman Khan]] cracked down on the uprisings with expulsion and massacre. |location=[[Hazarajat]], [[Afghanistan]] |date=1893 |time= |timezone= |fatalities=400,000 [[Hazaras]]{{cite web|title=H A Z A R A G E N O C I D E ( 1 8 8 8 - 1 8 9 3 )|url=https://accopulocrat.wixsite.com/hazaragenocide|website=Wixsite}} |perps =Afghan army under [[Abdur Rahman Khan]] }} {{Hazara people}} The third uprising of Hazara was in response to the harsh repression; the Hazara revolted again by early 1893. This revolt took the government forces by surprise and the Hazara managed to take most of Hazarajat back. However, after months of fighting, they were eventually defeated due to a shortage of food. Small pockets of resistance continued to the end of the year as government troops committed atrocities against civilians and deported entire villages. Abdur Rahman's subjugation of the Hazara due to fierce rebellion against the Afghan king gave birth to strong hatred between the Pahstun and Hazara for years to come. Massive forced displacements, especially in Oruzgan and [[Daychopan District|Daychopan]], continued as lands were confiscated and populations were expelled or fled. Some 35,000 families fled to northern Afghanistan, [[Mashhad]] (Iran) and [[Quetta]] (Pakistan). Hazara farmers were often forced to give up their property to Pashtuns{{Cite book|title = تاریخ باستانی هزاره ها|last = دلجو|first = عباس|publisher = انتشارات امیری|year = 2014|isbn = 9936801504|location = کابل|pages = }} and as a result many Hazara families had to leave seasonally to the [[List of cities in Afghanistan|major cities in Afghanistan]], Iran, or Pakistan in order to find jobs and a source of income. Quetta in Pakistan is home to the third largest settlements of Hazara outside Afghanistan. ==See also== {{Portal|Hazara people}} * [[Persecution of Hazara people]] * [[Persecution of Hazara people in Quetta]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1888-1893 Uprisings of Hazaras}} [[Category:Persecution of Hazara people|*]] [[Category:Human rights abuses in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Religious pluralism]] [[Category:Massacres in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Discrimination in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Ethnic cleansing in Asia]] [[Category:Hazarajat]] [[Category:Wars involving Afghanistan]]

revision.text: [[Image:Vank Cathedral - Heaven-Earth-Hell fresco.jpg|thumb|A fresco showing heaven above, and hell below, [[Vank Cathedral]], Iran]] The '''allegory of the long spoons''' is a [[parable]] that shows the difference between heaven and hell by means of people forced to eat with long spoons. It is attributed to Rabbi Haim of [[Rumšiškės|Romshishok]], as well as other sources.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-08-23/features/sns-201208221330--tms--godsqudctngs-a20120823-20120823_1_remarkable-story-heaven-text|title=Famous spiritual story varies among faiths and cultures, but carries the same message|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=22 October 2014}} In [[hell]] the people are unable to lift food to their mouths using such unwieldy cutlery, and are starving. In [[heaven]], the diners feed one another across the table and are sated. The story can encourage people to be kind to each other. There are [[#Interpretation|various interpretations]] of the fable including its [[#sermons|use in sermons]] and in advice to lonely people. == Interpretation == The story suggests that people have the opportunity to use what they are given (the long spoons in this allegory) to help nourish each other, but the problem, as Haim points out, lies in how the people treat each other. Given the same level playing field one group of people who treat each other well will create a pleasant environment. Whereas another group of people, given exactly the same tools to work with, can create unpleasant conditions simply by how they treat each other. Writer [[Dawn Eden]] suggests that this is a simple truth which can be easily forgotten by lonely people unable to see their situation clearly. She argues that such situations can be improved by reaching out to others. == Variations == The long spoons allegory has become part of the [[folklore]] of several cultures, for example: Jewish,{{cite web|last=Rabbi|first=Haim|title=Narrative of the allegory|url=http://www.hodu.com/parable.shtml|work=Citation source|publisher=Hodu|accessdate=6 Aug 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204060500/http://hodu.com/parable.shtml|archive-date=2011-02-04|dead-url=yes|df=}} Hindu,{{cite web|last=Lord|first=Shiva|title=Hindu parable: A Long Handled Spoon|url=http://www.forwardsteps.com.au/LongHandledSpoon.html|work=Swami|accessdate=5 Aug 2011}} Buddhist,{{cite book|last=Horn|first=Nils|title=Yoga Basic Knowledge and Exercises By|pages=30}} Oriental{{cite book|last=Peseschkian|first=Nossrat|title=Oriental stories as tools in psycho therapy|year=1986|publisher=Springer-Verlag|pages=26}} and Christian.{{cite book|last=Tietze|first=Harald W|title=Happyology|publisher=The Pope tells the story of the long spoons|pages=61}} In medieval Europe, the food in the story is a bowl of stew; in China, it is a bowl of rice being eaten with long chopsticks. In some versions of the story the diners are using regular cutlery but are unable to bend their arms, with a story attributed to Rabbi Haim of Romshishok describing how "both arms were splinted with wooden slats so he could not bend either elbow to bring the food to his mouth". During [[conflict resolution]] in non-Western cultures{{which|date=May 2014}} communicating difficult truths is better through a third party who can make suggestions through such stories.{{cite book|last=Swami|first=Vinod|title=Conflict Mediation Across Cultures|year=1992}} ==Art and popular culture== While the parable itself is seldom depicted in art, it is well known and used in sermons when referring to hell, where the fashion for depicting hell in terrible, painful, gruesome terms is fading in recent times.{{cite book|last=Eden|first=Dawn|title=The Thrill of the Chaste: Finding Fulfillment While Keeping Your Clothes On|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8499-1311-2|pages=194}} The parable is told by [[Norman McCay]] in the novelization of ''[[Kingdom Come (comics)|Kingdom Come]]''. In the 2011 [[Boardwalk Empire]] episode, "Under God's Power She Flourishes", Father Brennan tells Margaret the Allegory of the Long Spoons while Emily is fitted for leg braces.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2046372/synopsis?ref_=tt_ft|title="Boardwalk Empire" Under God's Power She Flourishes (2011) - Synopsis|work=IMDb|accessdate=22 October 2014}} A scene in the 2013 thriller ''[[The East (film)|The East]]'' draws strong comparisons to the allegory when protagonist Sarah is depicted as selfish for neglecting to feed her adjacent diner, whilst in a straitjacket. It is also retold in [[Barbara Kingsolver]]'s novel, ''[[The Bean Trees]]''. In Scotland, it is often said "It taks a lang spoon tae sup wi a [[Fife|Fifer]]". [[Caritas (charity)|Caritas]] made an animation video based on this allegory for their campaign "One human family, food for all".[http://food.caritas.org/video-one-human-family-food-for-all/ Caritas's Video "One human family, food for all"] ==See also== * [[Jewish folklore]] * [[Afterlife]] * [[World peace]] * ''[[Towards a Global Ethic: An Initial Declaration]]'' * [[The Golden Rule]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Allegory]] [[Category:Religious pluralism]] [[Category:Jewish folklore]] [[Category:Parables]] [[Category:Afterlife]] [[Category:Aid]]
